prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author's friend has been divorced five times, each time with a different father for her kids. The friend has been making comments that the author finds insulting, like questioning why the author is successful in dating while she isn't. The author finally tells her that it's because she has five kids with different dads and none of the fathers are paying child support, making it hard for someone to accept her. The friend gets angry and hangs up, and now mutual friends are saying the author is in the wrong, talking about privilege and entitlement.

First, I need to consider the dynamics of their friendship. The friend has been making personal and hurtful comments for two years, and the author has been brushing them off. Then, when the friend makes another comment, the author responds with something that points out the friend's situation as a possible reason for her dating struggles. 

The key here is whether the author's response was a valid and honest answer to the friend's question, or if it was a hurtful jab. The author says they were tired of the insults and felt it was the truth. However, even if it's true, the way it's delivered might be considered harsh. The friend might feel that the author is blaming her for her own situation, even if it's true. 

Also, the mutual friends are pointing out that the author has some privilege (like not being underweight) and that they're being entitled. The author defends themselves by saying they worked hard and aren't privileged. But in the context of the friend's life, which includes multiple divorces and single parenthood, the author's comment might come off as dismissive or judgmental. 

Even if the author's intention was to give a truthful answer to the friend's question, the timing and the context (after two years of insults) might make it seem like a retaliation rather than a helpful insight. Friends are supposed to support each other, and pointing out someone's flaws in that context can be damaging. 

Moreover, the friend's situation is complex and might have deeper issues that the author isn't considering. The author's response, while possibly true, could be perceived as reducing her struggles to just the issue of multiple children from different fathers, which isn't fair or empathetic. 

So, considering all these factors, the author might be in the wrong for responding in a way that was hurtful, even if it was a truthful observation. The friend's behavior was problematic, but the author's response could have been more compassionate. There might have been a better way to address the friend's question without attacking her situation. Therefore, the answer might be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) because the response was unkind and contributed to the conflict.
